reviewText: This is one of those movies that has an intriguing premise. Two people share an apartment but spend alternate nights there and are attracted to each other via clues but don't meet until the end. Unfortunately, the movie doesn't live up to its potential. It starts out being a bit confusing. The scenes are visually crowded and it is difficult to feel comfortable with what is going on. Second, there are all sorts of odd side details of the characters' lives that detract from the story rather than add to it. Romantic movies like this often have people in dead-end relationships that end up together. In the case of this movie, one of the characters is in an inexplicable relationship with a ridiculous character who is supposed to be a French actress and the other one is in what appears to be a relatively happy marriage. Rather than being humorous, many of the scenes end up being silly or difficult to believe. The characters aren't really developed all that much. They just sort of appear as stock characters and don't change much. I really like Matthew Broderick's movie Addicted to Love. This movie seems to have a lot of the same types of themes and ideas, but it is more like a dry run that didn't have all of the kinks worked out quite yet. I see that a lot of people have given this movie a positive review. For me, it just didn't quite fulfill the promise suggested by the premise. If this movie sounds good to you, do yourself a favor and check out Addicted to Love instead.
summary: Does not live up to its potential

reviewText: I loved this perfectly cast, charming flick.  This is the New York scene for the single Sam (Matthew Broderick) who is looking for someone who will care about him. He finds an apartment that he can have two nights a week where he can be alone as the apartment he sub-lets is virtually full of people. He is not looking for anything long-termed as he believes he can't handle that since his last relationship has failed.  But then there is Ellen (Annabella Sciorra) who shares that apartment another two days a week.  Sam cooks, Ellen Paints. They share notes and finally when you might think they will never meet because of various circumstances, they do.  It ends as you would hope, happily.

reviewText: This movie makes you want to help these two people find each other. . All you romantics will be captivated by the story line, the couple and the cruel twist of fate that keeps them apart.  I bet you'll be wanting to help them too. "Matthew Broderick"(Sam) a gourmet chef,needing some peace and quiet,  and "Annabella Sciorra" (Ellen) a dental hygienist, wanting a place where she can paint,  each sublease an apartment for (2) days a week . The actual tenant of the apartment who  is soon to be married and doesn't want to give the apartment up, as he and his frat buddies meet there a few nights a week themselves. Decided  to sublease the apartment for the remaining days in the week in order to keep it. I don't want to spoil things for anyone by giving away too much, but I hope I've said just enough to peek your interest. Rent or buy this movie, you 'll be glad you did!
summary: True love will always find a way
Title: N/A

reviewText: I wasn't sure if I should give this movie a 2 or 3 star rating.  I settled on a 3 because even though the movie didn't live up to expectations, it did have good moments.  There were times when it felt like it was all over the place.  It should have focused more on Sam and Ellen, and less on the frat boy who didn't want to give up his bachelor pad.  There should have been more moments where Sam and Ellen connected even though they hadn't met.  I also think the character of Ellen shouldn't have been married.  Maybe she could have been written as someone who was in a long term relationship and living with a man who she was slowly falling out of love with.  Instead she came across as someone who was selfish while her husband was trying to make their marriage work (he bought her a house for goodness sake - what did the man have to do to make her happy????).I also found Jeanne Tripplehorn so annoying.  I couldn't understand her half the time.  What a waste of her talent.  Doris Roberts was also wasted in this movie.  With so many talented actors, this could have been sooooo much better.  But like I said, there were some nice moments, and it's not the worse movie I have ever seen.  Hence the 3 :-)
summary: Great Idea which didn't quite work

reviewerName: Strommy "I yam what I yam, and that's all wha...
reviewText: I almost fell out of my chair when I saw this delightful movie finally released on dvd. It is one of my all time favorites and I had been waiting for years to finally see it released on dvd. I was a little disappointed that there are no extras whatsoever, but hey at least I got the movie.Anyway it is a "Chick Flick" comedy that a guy can like. Yes it is a light, but very entertaining movie about how the lives of three "opposites" intersect; Sam the cultured, pseudo-artsy, wannabee Chef, Ellen the disillusioned wife looking for her own space and Brian the Stockbroker party animal. Will the lives of these three people remain separate or will circumstances allow them to meet, even though they are never at the apartment on the same days? This is a nice film with a clever story and script. Only in the Big Apple, I suppose, would you find folks willing to rent a place for only two nights a week. The cast is terrific, with Broderick, especially, giving a very funny and touching performance. As for the costumes, sets and production values, they are great, resulting in a movie that looks mighty nice. If you are a romantic comedy fan, you can't miss this one! Its fresh plot elements and well-drawn characters make it a welcome find in the world of light-hearted love stories. Yet, even if you are not a regular romcom viewer, the film still has some funny situations and universal themes that make it a diverting watch for most anyone.
